revision.text:
The '''well-made play''' ({{lang-fr|la pièce bien faite}}, pronounced {{IPA-fr|pjɛs bjɛ̃ fɛt|}}) is a [[Drama|dramatic genre]] from [[nineteenth-century theatre]] first codified by French dramatist [[Eugène Scribe]]. Dramatists [[Victorien Sardou]], [[Alexandre Dumas, fils]], and [[Emile Augier]] wrote within the genre, each putting a distinct spin on the style. The well-made play was a popular form of entertainment. By the mid-19th century, however, it had already entered into common use as a derogatory term.<ref name="cgt">Banham (1998), 964, 972–3, 1191–2.</ref> [[Henrik Ibsen]] and the other [[Realism (theatre)|realistic]] dramatists of the later 19th century ([[August Strindberg]], [[Gerhart Hauptmann]], [[Émile Zola]], [[Anton Chekhov]]) built upon its technique of careful construction and preparation of effects in the genre [[problem play]]. "Through their example", Marvin Carlson explains, "the well-made play became and still remains the traditional model of [[Dramaturgy|play construction]]."<ref name="carlson">Carlson (1993, 216).</ref> [[File:Scribe Eugène 2.jpg|210px|thumb| Eugène Scribe]]
In the English language, that tradition found its early 20th-century codification in Britain in the form of [[William Archer (critic)|William Archer]]'s ''Play-Making: A Manual of Craftmanship'' (1912),<ref>Archer, William. Playmaking: a Manual of Craftsmanship. Public domain. https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/10865</ref> and in the United States with [[George Pierce Baker]]'s ''Dramatic Technique'' (1919).<ref>J L Styan, ''Modern Drama in Theory and Practice I'', quoted by Innes (2000, 7).</ref>
==Form== [[File:Aristotle's Tragic Plot Structure.pdf|thumb|Aristotle's Tragic Plot Structure]]
The form has a strong [[Neoclassicism|Neoclassical]] flavour, involving a tight [[plot (narrative)|plot]] and a [[climax (narrative)|climax]] that takes place close to the end of the play. The well-made play retains the shape of [[Aristotle]]'s ideal [[Greek tragedy|Greek-tragedy]] model outlined in his ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]''.<ref>The Internet Classics Archive by Daniel C. Stevenson, Web Atomics. Web. 11 Dec. 2014. http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/poetics.html</ref><ref>Aristotle. "Poetics". Trans. Ingram Bywater. The Project Gutenberg EBook. Oxford: Clarendon P, 2 May 2009. Web. 26 Oct. 2014.</ref>
The well-made play can be broken down into a specific set of criteria.<ref name="Camille and Other Plays">{{cite book|last1=Scribe|first1=Eugene|last2=ed. introd. Stanton |first2=Stephen|title=Camille and Other Plays|date=1956|publisher=Hill and Wang|isbn=0809007061}}</ref> First, the story depends upon a key piece of information kept from some characters, but known to others (and to the audience). Most of the story takes place before the action of the play begins, making the beginning of the play a late point of attack. Exposition during act one explains actions that precede the opening scene, and generates the audience's sympathy for the hero (or heroes) over their rival (or rivals). The plot moves forward in a chain of actions that use minor reversals of fortune to create suspense. The pace builds towards a climactic obligatory scene, in which the hero triumphs. This scene contains a climactic reversal of fortune, or [[peripeteia]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=McBride|first1=Augusto Boal ; translated by Charles A. & Maria-Odilia Leal|title=Theatre of the oppressed|date=1985|publisher=Theatre Communications Group|location=New York|isbn=0930452496|edition=5th print.}}</ref> A dénouement follows, in which all remaining plot points are unraveled and resolved.<ref name="Camille and Other Plays"/>
A recurrent device that the well-made play employs is the use of letters or papers falling into unintended hands, in order to bring about [[plot twists]] and climaxes.<ref name="Camille and Other Plays"/> The letters bring about an unexpected and climactic reversal of fortune, in which it is often revealed that someone is not who they pretend to be. Mistaken or mysterious identity as a basis for plot complications is referred to as ''qui pro quo''.<ref name="Stanton, Shaw's Debt to Scribe">{{cite journal|last1=Stanton|first1=Stephen S.|title=Shaw's Debt to Scribe|journal=MLA|date=December 1961|volume=76|issue=5|pages=575–585}}</ref><ref>Holmgren, Beth. "Acting Out: Qui pro Quo in the Context of Interwar Warsaw." East European Politics & Societies (2012): 0888325412467053.</ref>
[[Eugene Scribe]] contributed over 300 plays and opera libretti to the dramatic literature canon. Thirty-five of these works are considered well-made-plays.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Encyclopædia Britannica Editors|title=well-made play|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/639300/well-made-play|website=Encyclopædia Britannica Online|accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref>
==History== ===French Neoclassicism: a standard form=== History of French Neoclassic form lays a critical foundation for Scribe, who draws upon devices determined by the [[French Academy]] to create his dramatic structure. French Neoclassicism conceives of [[Verisimilitude]], or the appearance of a plausible truth, as the aesthetic goal of a play.<ref name="Ashgate Publishing, Ltd">{{cite book|last1=Ibbett|first1=Katherine|title=The Style of the State in French Theater, 1630-1660: Neoclassicism and Government.|date=2009|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.,}}</ref> In 1638, the [[French Academy]] codified a system by which dramatists could achieve Verisimilitude in a verdict on the [[Pierre Corneille|Le Cid debate]].<ref name="Ashgate Publishing, Ltd"/> The monarchy enforced the standards of French Neoclassicism with a system of censorship under which funding and practice permits were issued to a limited number of theater companies.<ref name="Brockett & Hildy">{{cite book|last1=Hildy|first1=Franklin J.|last2=Brockett|first2=Oscar G.|title=History of the theatre|date=2007|publisher=Allyn and Bacon|location=Boston, Mass. [u.a.]|isbn=0-205-47360-1|edition=Foundation}}</ref> This system underwent small modifications, but remained essentially the same up until the [[French Revolution]]. Until then, restrictive laws inhibited the growth of new practices with the exception of those advocated by a few intrepid dramatists such as [[Voltaire]], [[Diderot]], and [[Beaumarchais]]. After the [[French Revolution]], adherence to the form became an artistic choice instead of a political necessity.
===Boulevard theatres: new forms=== Although Scribe drew heavily upon Neoclassic devices, he used them in original ways that would not have been acceptable without new popular forms, such as those developed at the Boulevard theatres.<ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Frederick|title=Theater and Revolution: the culture of the French stage|date=1980|publisher=Viking Press|location=New York}}</ref> In order to work around the formal monopoly of the [[Comédie Française]] in the middle of the 18th century, theater troupes experimenting with new dramatic forms sprang up along the Boulevard du Temple. Their aim was to escape the censors, and please the public. Popular reception of the boulevard theatres' explorations helped to crack the edifice of Neoclassic form.<ref name="History of the theatre">{{cite book|last1=Hildy|first1=Oscar G. Brockett ; Franklin J.|title=History of the theatre|date=2007|publisher=Allyn and Bacon|location=Boston, Mass. [u.a.]|isbn=0-205-47360-1|edition=Foundation}}</ref> After the French Revolution, French theater opened to the influence of practices that had meanwhile developed in other places around Europe.<ref name="French Revolution, Carlson">{{cite book|last1=Carlson|first1=Marvin A.|title=The Theatre of the French Revolution|date=1966|publisher=Cornell UP|location=Ithaca, NY}}</ref>
Scribe's development of a form that could be used repeatedly to turn out new material suited the demands of a growing middle class theater audience.<ref name=Stanton>{{cite book|last1=Stanton|first1=edited, with an introduction to the well-made play by Stephen S.|title=Camille, and other plays|date=1999|publisher=Hill and Wang|location=New York|isbn=0809007061}}</ref>
==Criticism== ===On Scribe, Dumas fils, Augier, and Sardou===
Scribe's influence on theater, according to Marvin J. Carlson, "cannot be overestimated".<ref name="Cornell UP">{{cite book|last1=Carlson|first1=Marvin|title=Theories of the Theatre: A Historical and Critical Survey from the Greeks to the Present|date=1984|publisher=Cornell UP|location=Ithaca and London}}</ref> Carlson observes that, unlike other influential theater thinkers, Scribe did not write prefaces or manifestos declaiming his ideas. Scribe influenced theater, instead, with craftsmanship. He honed a dramatic form into a reliable mould that could be applied not only to different content, but to different content from a variety of playwrights. Carlson identifies a single instance of Scribe's critical commentary from a speech Scribe gave to the Académie française in 1836. Scribe expressed his view of what draws the audiences to theater:
"not for instruction or improvement, but for diversion and distraction, and that which diverts them [audience] most is not truth, but fiction. To see again what you have before your eyes daily will not please you, but that which is not available to you in every day life - the extraordinary and the romantic."<ref name="Cornell UP"/>
Although Scribe advocated for a theater of amusement over didacticism, other writers, beginning with [[Alexandre Dumas, fils]], adopted Scribe's structure to create didactic plays. In a letter to a critic, Dumas ''fils'' states,"... if I can find some means to force people to discuss the problem, and the lawmaker to revise the law, I shall have done more than my duty as a writer, I shall have done my duty as a man.".<ref name="History of the theatre"/> Dumas' thesis plays are plays written in the well-made style that take clear moral positions on social issues of the day. [[Emile Augier]] also used Scribe's formula to write plays addressing contemporary social issues, although he declares his moral position less strongly.<ref>Taylor, John Russell. The Rise and Fall of the Well-Made Play, Great Britain: Routledge, Cox and Wyman, Ltd.,1967. Print.</ref>
By the late 19th century, the well-made play had fallen out of critical favor.<ref>Banham, Martin, ed. 1998. The Cambridge Guide to Theatre. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-43437-8}}.</ref> Shaw was among those who held the form in low regard, "Why the devil should a man write like Scribe when he can write like Shakespeare or Moliere, Aristophanes or Euripides? Who was Scribe that he should dictate to me or anyone else how a play should be written?"<ref name="Stanton, Shaw's Debt to Scribe" /> In reference to the form's tendency to favor amusing plot twists over complexly drawn characters, Shaw referred to the genre as Sardoodledom after [[Victorien Sardou]], who also wrote in the well-made style.<ref name="Stanton, Shaw's Debt to Scribe" />
===Shaw and Ibsen=== The opening to the preface to ''Three Plays by Brieux'' offers another example of Shavian disdain for the well-made plays. Shaw identifies the process of creating them as an industry, and their creators as “literary mechanics” instead of artists. To convey how vulgar he finds a widely used playwrighting formula, Shaw interprets the aphorism "Art for art's sake," as "Success for money's sake."<ref>Shaw, George Bernard. ‘’Three Plays by Brieux’’. New York: Brentano’s, 1911.</ref>
In an essay published in [[Modern Language Association|PMLA]] in 1951, ''Pygmalion: Bernard Shaw’s Dramatic Theory and Practice'', Milton Crane reasons that Shaw’s disparagement of the classic well-made formula, and his desire to pry Ibsen’s work away from association with the works of Scribe and Sardou, serve a specific agenda. Crane argues that Shaw aims to prevent his own use of the well-made formula from linking his plays with work considered out of fashion. Shaw’s theory of the [[problem play]] and discussion ideas align his plays with Ibsen’s, and distinguishes them from stale plays of the past. Crane observes that Shaw, by his own admission, learned dramatic structure from contemporary popular theatre which was then dominated by the well-made formula.<ref name="Stanton, Shaw's Debt to Scribe" /> Crane goes on to argue how that formula is present in [[List of works by George Bernard Shaw|''Pygmalion'', ''Man and Superman'', and ''The Doctor’s Dilemma'']].<ref>Crane, Milton. "Pygmalion: Bernard Shaw's Dramatic Theory and Practice." PMLA 66.6 (1951): 879-85. JSTOR [JSTOR]. Web. 4 May 2015.</ref>
====The problem play==== [[File:Henrik Ibsen as a young man.jpg|thumb|Henrik Ibsen as a young man]]
Shaw discusses the notion of the [[problem play]] in an essay of the same title published in 1895.<ref name="Problem Play from Shaw on Theatre">{{cite book|last1=Shaw|first1=George Bernard|editor1-last=West|editor1-first=E.J.|title=Shaw on Theatre|date=1958|publisher=Hill & Wang|location=New York|chapter=Problem Play}}</ref> He defines a problem play as one that puts a person or people in conflict with an institution, confronting a contemporary social question. He cites the "Woman question" as a contemporary example. Ibsen's engagement with the "Woman question" in ''[[A Doll's House]]'' and ''[[Ghosts (play)|Ghosts]]'' qualifies those works as problem plays. Shaw distinguishes between the problem play and literature with conflicts reflecting a more universal view of the human condition. Works whose fundamental conflict does not pit human against institution, he argues, are more apt to remain relevant through generations. He cites ''[[Hamlet]]'', ''[[Goethe's Faust|Faust]]'', and ''[[Les Misérables]]'' as examples of stories whose conflicts involve more eternal human questions. Shaw observes that the immediacy of the institutional question addressed in a problem play will render the play "flat as ditchwater" once society progresses and the issue is resolved.<ref name="Problem Play from Shaw on Theatre" /> Although Ibsen was hailed by feminists, he did not regard himself as an advocate for any particular group.<ref>Innes, Christopher. "Henrik Ibsen, Speech at the Festival of the Norwegian Women's Rights League, Christiana, 26 May 1898." A Sourcebook on Naturalist Theatre. London: Routledge, 2000. 74-75. Print.</ref>
====The well-made play and modern drama==== Ibsen's aim, according to Raymond Williams, was to express tragedies in the human condition. Ibsen qualifies a human tragedy as the state "[when a person] stands in a tight place; he cannot go forwards or backwards.”<ref name=Williams>{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Raymond|title=Drama from Ibsen to Brecht|date=1973|publisher=Penguin|location=Harmondsworth|isbn=978-0140214925|edition=2nd rev.}}</ref> Williams also cites the specific characteristic that distinguishes his and Ibsen's modern drama from the preceding well-made formula. The well-made formula, Shaw observes, can be divided into three sections: Exposition, Situation, Unraveling. The plays of Ibsen and Shaw, Shaw himself asserts, do not end with a classic unraveling. Their work can be divided as: Exposition, Situation, Discussion.<ref name="Williams"/>
==Offshoots== [[Oscar Wilde|Oscar Wilde's]] ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest]]'' exaggerates many of the conventions of the well-made play, such as the missing papers conceit (the hero, as an infant, was confused with the manuscript of a novel) and a final revelation (which, in this play, occurs about thirty seconds before the final curtain).<ref name="Stanton, Shaw's Debt to Scribe" />
[[Henrik Ibsen|Henrik Ibsen's]] ''[[A Doll's House]]'' follows most of the conceits of the well-made play, but transcends the genre when, after incriminating papers are recovered, Nora rejects the expected return to normality. Several of Ibsen's subsequent plays build on the general construction principles of the well-made play. ''[[The Wild Duck]]'' (1884) can be seen as a deliberate, meta-theatrical deconstruction of the [[Eugène Scribe|Scribean]] formula. Ibsen sought a compromise between [[Naturalism (theatre)|Naturalism]] and the well-made play which was fraught with difficulties since life does not fall easily into either form.<ref>Elsom, John. ''Post-War British Theatre''. London: Routledge, 1976, p. 40.</ref>
Although [[George Bernard Shaw]] scorned the "well-made play", he accepted the form, and even thrived by it, for it concentrated his skills on the conversation among characters, his greatest asset as a dramatist.<ref>Elsom, John. ''Post-War British Theatre''. London: Routledge, 1976, p. 43.</ref> Other classic twists on the well-made play can be seen in his use of the General's coat and the hidden photograph in ''[[Arms and the Man]]''.
Also, [[J. B. Priestley]]'s 1946 ''[[An Inspector Calls]]'' may in some ways be considered a "well-made play" in that its action happens before the play starts, and in the case of the older Birlings no moral change takes place. The similarity between Priestley's play and this rather conservative genre might strike some readers/audiences as surprising because Priestley was a socialist. However, his play, like Ibsen's ''A Doll's House'' transcends this genre by providing another plunge into chaos after the return to normality. He replaced the dramatic full stop with a question mark by revealing in the last scene that the 'inspector' who has exposed the complicity of a prosperous industrial family in the murder or suicide of a working-class girl, is not an inspector at all (perhaps a practical joker, an emanation of the world to come, or a manifestation of the world to come), and the curtain falls on the news that a real girl has died and a real inspector is on the way.<ref>Elsom, John. ''Post-War British Theatre''. London: Routledge, 1976, p. 45.</ref>
The techniques of well-made plays also lend themselves to comedies of situation, often [[farce]]. In ''[[Quintessence of Ibsenism|The Quintessence of Ibsenism]]'', [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]] proposed that [[Ibsen]] converted this formula for use in "serious" plays by substituting discussion for the plausible dénouement or conclusion. Thus, plays become open-ended, as if there were life for the [[protagonist]]s beyond the last act curtain.<ref>Shaw, Bernard. The Quintessence of Ibsenism. New York: Brentano's, 1913. Print. [https://archive.org/details/quintessenceofib00shawrich]</ref>

The '''Welsh Seal''', ({{lang-cy|Sêl Gymreig}}), is a [[seal (emblem)|seal]] used for [[Wales]]. Provision for a Welsh seal was made in Part 4 of the [[Government of Wales Act 2006]] which also designated the [[First Minister of Wales]] as "Keeper of the Welsh Seal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2006/32/section/116|title=Government of Wales Act 2006|website=Legislation.gov.uk|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> The seal is used by the First Minister to seal (and so bring into force) [[letters patent]] signed by the monarch giving [[Royal Assent]] to bills passed by the [[National Assembly for Wales]] in order for those bills to become [[Act of the National Assembly for Wales|Acts of the Assembly]].
==Design== The basic form of the seal was approved by the First Minister of Wales in January 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wales.gov.uk/publications/accessinfo/drnewhomepage/governmentdrs/2011/welshsealdesign/;jsessionid=HcVXN1zTpt7b2MJftZwrnNx87Cp3M2TBbF8jsvLYFyN52QxdN1M1!-547148533?lang=en|title=Welsh Government : 'Publications' has moved|website=wales.gov.uk|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> The seal is one-sided and represents both the monarch and the Welsh nation;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/news/New-seal-Welsh-laws/article-3314895-detail/article.html|title=Swansea: The latest news, sport, what's on and business from Swansea and Gower|website=Thisissouthwales.co.uk|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> it also features the [[Royal Badge of Wales]]. The final design of the seal was decided on 23 June 2011 by the Royal Mint Advisory Committee on the Design of Coins, Medals, Seals and Decorations, with the advice of the [[College of Arms]]. The design was made public in December 2011, following a visit by First Minister Carwyn Jones to [[The Royal Mint]] where the seal was about to be made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caerphillyobserver.co.uk/news/412772/first-minister-sees-first-welsh-seal-since-time-of-owain-glyndwr/|title=First Minister sees first Welsh seal since time of Owain Glyndwr - Caerphilly.Observer|date=2 December 2011|website=Caerphillyobserver.co.uk|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> Queen [[Elizabeth II]] formally delivered the seal into the custody of the First Minister at a meeting of the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] at [[Buckingham Palace]], London, on 14 December 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://privycouncil.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/12/Orders-approved-at-Privy-Council-14-December-2011.pdf|format=PDF|title=Orders Approved by the Privy Council|website=Privycouncil.independent.gov.uk|accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-12639379|title = What happens next after the assembly powers referendum?|date = 2011-03-05|newspaper = [[BBC News]]|language = en-GB|access-date = 2016-09-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-16202209|title=Signed, sealed, delivered: Queen approves Welsh seal|date=15 December 2011|accessdate=21 August 2017|website=Bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==List of Keepers of the Welsh Seal==
The Government of Wales Act 2006 designated the [[First Minister of Wales]] as "Keeper of the Welsh Seal" ({{lang-cy|Geidwad Sêl Gymreig}}). *2011 – present: [[Carwyn Jones]]
